p: The HIV epidemic in Uganda and many countries in sub Saharan Africa is now mature and generalized. In the late 1980’s and early 1990’s, Uganda experienced a sharp increase in the incidence of HIV cases, but due to several concerted prevention efforts, followed by behavior change, HIV incidence reduced significantly [ 1– 3]. In 2000, Uganda became the first country in sub Saharan Africa to register success in reducing number of new cases of HIV [ 4]. However, the fortunes reversed and subsequent studies started to show that HIV incidence was no longer falling [ 5]. More recent studies now show the incidence is in fact very high in some groups such as fishing populations [ 6, 7], which spills over into the general population [ 8]. The factors responsible for this negative trend are poorly understood.
